nodes.text: Existing selective instruction duplication (SID) protections evaluated on a single program input can fail to provide the claimed silent data corruption (SDC) coverage when the protected program runs with different inputs

Fault injection experiments across multiple random inputs show that SDC coverage provided by state-of-the-art SID can drop substantially compared to expected coverage measured with a single reference input

A small set of program instructions, called incubative instructions, exhibit input-dependent error propagation: near-zero SDC probability under a reference input but much higher SDC probability under other inputs, causing coverage loss
Re-prioritizing and protecting incubative instructions across multiple inputs can mitigate the observed loss of SDC coverage

Measured over 11 benchmarks, average expected SDC coverage from SID fell from 96.12% to 58.76% when evaluated across multiple inputs; per-benchmark input fractions causing coverage loss averaged 37.58% (max 72% in FFT)
Empirical observation: some benchmarks show extreme variability (e.g., Kmeans SDC coverage range 0%â€“100% across inputs) while others are stable (e.g., LU, Pathfinder)

Definition and identification rule for incubative instructions: instructions with benefits in the last 1% under one input but outside the last 30% under other inputs, indicating large input-dependent benefit variance
Incubative instructions constitute on average 15.79% of instructions per program (range 6.20% to 32.09%) and are responsible for at least 97% of the observed SDC coverage loss

MINPSID: an automated framework that (a) measures per-instruction cost and benefit on a reference input, (b) uses a genetic algorithm guided input search with weighted control-flow graphs to find inputs revealing incubative instructions, and (c) re-prioritizes incubative instructions for SID selection

Weighted CFG fitness: for each candidate input, MINPSID profiles dynamic basic-block edge counts to form a weighted CFG, converts it to an indexed list, and scores inputs by average Euclidean distance from prior inputs to drive GA mutations and crossover

MINPSID updates benefits of identified incubative instructions to their observed upper bounds across generated inputs and runs the knapsack-based SID selection using these conservative benefits before code transformation for duplication

Evaluation: MINPSID reduces SDC coverage variability and mitigates 97% of SID coverage loss on average across the 11 benchmarks; average percentage of inputs causing coverage loss falls from 37.58% (baseline) to 8.36% (MINPSID)
Efficiency: MINPSID's input-search engine identifies 45.60% more incubative instructions than a blind random search within the same time budget and converges with fewer inputs, improving mitigation

Cost: MINPSID requires a one-time analysis overhead (measuring and FI) averaging 63.71 minutes per benchmark on the authors' machines (baseline SID preparation ~3.87 minutes); per-instruction FI to find incubative instructions averages 26.42 minutes
MINPSID produces more conservative expected SDC coverage estimates (due to using upper-bound benefits for incubative instructions), yielding more predictable minimum coverage across protection levels
